title: Mario Gotze recovering in Munich as Borussia Dortmund confirm he won't play again this season

Borussia Dortmund are hopeful that Mario Gotze will be fit for the start of next season, as the German star continues his rehabilitation in Munich. 
Gotze, 24, has been ruled out of action for the foreseeable future after what was termed “a comprehensive internal investigation” into his injury problems last month revealed a metabolic disorder. 
The World Cup winner returned to BVB last summer from Bayern Munich in a £20million deal, but struggled with injuries and made just 16 appearances for Thomas Tuchel’s men. 
Since the winter break, he had featured for only 29 minutes, before being pulled out of training in February. Gotze won't be rushed back as he looks to fully recover (Photo: Rex Features) Read More Jack Wilshere sends get well soon message to stricken Dortmund star Gotze 
An update on his condition, released by BVB, declared: "If he responds positively to treatment, Götze can start back training in early summer. The midfield player is currently undergoing rehab and an individual training programme. 
"The long term target for the player is to be fully fit and ready to play for the start of next season 
Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke added: "BVB wishes Mario Götze a fast recovery, also in the name of their ten million fans." 
Gotze is now back in Bavaria, where he is surrounded by his family as he continues working on his recovery. Gotze’s brother, Felix, played for Bayern’s Under-19 side, while his father, Jurgen, and older brother Fabian, both also live there. 
The 62-cap star has also been to visit Dr Hans-Wilhelm Muller-Wohlfahrt, whom he knows well from his time at Bayern. Gotze's World Cup winner (Photo: Action Images) Gotze won't return to training until the summer (Photo: Bongarts/Getty Images) 
Gotze’s problems stem from nutritional issues, and his muscle problems are linked both to his diet and enzymes in his body struggling to convert food to energy. That has led to repetitive muscle injuries, which have unfortunately been a regular occurrence during his career. 
As such, a big part of his rehab has been changes to his diet. Gotze has recently been seen frequenting the Brenner Grill in Munich’s Maximilianstraße, with super foods like quinoa, avocado and hemp seeds an increasingly key component in Gotze's diet, with they and similar foods a key aid in Gotze’s recovery. 
BVB hope to have the player ready for their pre-season tour of China in the International Champions Cup. 
Despite the club's continued participation in the Champions League and their battle to finish in the Bundesliga top four, they have no intention of looking to rush Gotze until he is fully fit and ready.
